ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This course covers Latin grammar. The textbook is a little strange, but the teachers know what to do with it. This course is a great introduction to Latin, although it is intended to be taken as the first step of learning Latin. I would only recommend this to those who intend to continue with Latin afterwards.
yes, if they are willing to put in the effort

Latin 110 was a great class to gain the basics of Latin as somebody who had never taken a class or really encountered the language before. For somebody wanting to start the language, I would definitely recommend the class. Coming out of the first semester, I know all the verb conjugations and noun declensions and a lot of grammar. Furthermore, I can apply my skills to real-life(ish) situations i.e. reading inscriptions on statues and translating the text of songs. At the end of the course, I was astounded by how much I had learned.
If you want to learn Latin, Yale's Latin department is a fantastic place to learn it. The only question to ask is, do I want to learn Latin? What's the value to learning this "dead" language?
Absolutely! A wonderful language, and Tom was a great teacher. You can read real Roman pieces by the end of the semester (albeit with the help of a dictionary).
I would recommend it if you are ok with the work.
It's a great class anyone should take if they have never learned Latin before. Latin's very structured and grammatically complex; so it could take a little getting used to for disorganized minds.
